channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Army unit members 'killed civilians'
item.description: An undercover British army unit operating in Belfast during the Troubles killed unarmed civilians, former members have told BBC One's Panorama.

item.title: Arrested Paris gun suspect named
item.description: French authorities name a man arrested on suspicion of gun attacks in Paris as Abdelhakim Dekhar, earlier jailed in a notorious criminal case.

item.title: Rebel MPs defeated over Army changes
item.description: An attempt by Tory rebels to delay plans to recruit more reservists to offset a reduction in regular Army numbers is defeated in the Commons.

item.title: Briton in Syria fights with al-Qaeda
item.description: A British man in Syria tells the BBC he is fighting for a group linked to al-Qaeda because it is his duty and Muslims are "being slaughtered".

item.title: Co-op Bank to face Flowers inquiry
item.description: Chancellor George Osborne is to order an independent inquiry into how Paul Flowers was deemed a suitable chairman of the Co-op Bank.

item.title: Key Iranian nuclear talks resume
item.description: Talks resume in Geneva to try to secure an agreement on Iran's nuclear programme, but its Supreme Leader warns it must not be "pressured".

item.title: UK 'let NSA store email addresses'
item.description: The UK allowed the US's National Security Agency to keep mobile phone numbers and email addresses of ordinary Britons from 2007, reports say.

item.title: Afghan-US security deal 'finalised'
item.description: The US says it has reached agreement with Afghan officials on the text of a deal paving the way for some US troops to remain after 2014.

item.title: Four dead and one injured in fire
item.description: Two women and two brothers who died in a house fire in north Derbyshire are named by police.

item.title: Scotland gay marriage bill endorsed
item.description: Legislation to introduce same-sex marriage in Scotland is approved in principle by parliament, after MSPs vote on it for the first time.

item.title: Murdoch agrees divorce settlement
item.description: Media mogul Rupert Murdoch and third wife Wendi Deng agree on the terms of a divorce to end their 14-year marriage, in an undisclosed settlement.

item.title: Hull to be UK City of Culture 2017
item.description: Hull is named the UK's next City of Culture, beating Leicester, Dundee and Swansea Bay to the right to hold the title in 2017.

item.title: R2-D2 confirmed for Star Wars movie
item.description: Android R2-D2 is to appear in the next Star Wars film, and is being created and maintained by two British robot building fans.

item.title: Armstrong settles bonuses lawsuit
item.description: Disgraced former cyclist Lance Armstrong settles a lawsuit with an insurance company over bonuses he was paid while doping.

item.title: Vonn re-injures right knee in crash
item.description: Olympic downhill champion Lindsey Vonn is recovering after re-injuring her right knee in a crash on Tuesday.

item.title: Broncos to go into administration
item.description: Super League side London Broncos announce their intention to go into administration.

item.title: From Sydney to Strictly Come Dancing
item.description: Ten years on from England's World Cup victory, Strictly Come Dancing star Ben Cohen tells Ben Dirs he 'doesn't miss rugby at all'

item.title: Australia plot England's Ashes demise
item.description: Aggressive Australia are confident of an Ashes win against an undercooked and unsure England side, writes Tom Fordyce

item.title: Bank says UK in sustained recovery
item.description: The UK economy is in a sustained recovery and does not face major inflation risks, according to the Bank of England's latest minutes.

item.title: VIDEO: Women's journeys from 'saris to suits'
item.description: Twelve compelling stories of the struggles of South Asian-American women as they strive for success are featured in a calendar called Saris to Suits.

item.title: Cameron drugs 'banter' angers MP
item.description: David Cameron clashes with a veteran Labour MP in the Commons after joking that he must have been taking "mind-altering substances".

item.title: VIDEO: 'So many things are going wrong with it'
item.description: A Tory MP and former solider has called on the defence secretary to pause with his plans to offset cuts of 20,000 to regular troops by expanding the Army Reserve to 30,000.

item.title: A&Es get extra money as winter bites
item.description: The government is expected to make an extra £150m available for A&E units in England as they gear up for what looks set to be a tough winter, the BBC understands.

item.title: VIDEO: Translating medicine into art
item.description: BBC Africa's Sophie Ikenye visits an exhibition at the Wellcome Collection, in London, where global attitudes to medicine are translated into art.

item.title: Warning of language skills shortage
item.description: The UK has an "alarming shortage" of people able to speak the 10 languages vital to future prosperity and global standing, warns a report.

item.title: AUDIO: UK 'needs foreign language speakers'
item.description: 5 live reporter Rowan Bridge visits Manchester College to find out why are British students so behind with languages.

item.title: LG investigates 'spying' Smart TVs
item.description: Manufacturer LG is investigating a report that at least one of its Smart TV models sends back viewing habits data even when a privacy setting is activated.

item.title: VIDEO: High-tech solution to eliminate acne
item.description: Scan Z say their smartphone accessory and app can predict and prevent acne. Technology reporter Dave Lee tried it for himself.

item.title: Nobel Prize winner Sanger dies at 95
item.description: Frederick Sanger, the British biochemist who twice won the Nobel Prize, has died at the age of 95.

item.title: VIDEO: How to rear genetically modified flies
item.description: Researcher Martha Koukidou from Oxitec explains how to rear GM fruit flies in preparation for the first European field trial of the insects.

item.title: BBC presenter Ray Gosling dies at 74
item.description: Journalist, broadcaster and gay rights activist Ray Gosling dies in hospital in Nottingham.

item.title: VIDEO: Old Boy gets a Hollywood makeover
item.description: Director Spike Lee has a new film out called Oldboy, inspired by the Japanese graphic novel and 2003 South Korean classic cult film of the same name.

item.title: VIDEO: The man who can taste the Tube map
item.description: James Wannerton has a condition called synaesthesia, which links senses normally experienced separately.

item.title: Insect eating creeps on to Paris menus
item.description: The French would have a fancy word for it - entomophagy. Insect-eating to you and me. Hugh Schofield looks at the rise of insect-eating in France.

item.title: 'Abducted' children to return to UK
item.description: A north London mother wins a ruling to get her children back from Russia after they were abducted by their father.

item.title: 'Baby in cupboard' midwife cautioned
item.description: A midwife who left a baby face down in a stationery cupboard is given a three-year caution order.

item.title: Tourism 'fundamental' to job growth
item.description: Tourism could play a "fundamental role" in job creation and economic growth over the next decade, Visit Scotland's chairman says

item.title: Pricing nature 'may help save it'
item.description: Business leaders and environmentalists meeting at an Edinburgh forum say putting an economic value on nature could be the best way to protect it.

item.title: Housing contracts: No fraud evidence
item.description: A report into multi-million pound overpayments to Housing Executive contractors finds no evidence of fraud or corruption.

item.title: Victims condemn NI prosecutions call
item.description: Northern Ireland victims groups criticise a suggestion that there should be an end to prosecutions for Troubles killings.

item.title: Partner's focus on activist's return
item.description: The partner of a Greenpeace activist bailed by a Russian court after a ship protest in the Arctic says she is now focussed on getting him home to Wales.

item.title: Coroner praises sea rescue tourists
item.description: The bravery of two holidaymakers who went into a rough sea risking their own lives to try to rescue a father and his sons is praised by a coroner.

item.title: LRA leader Kony 'in surrender talks'
item.description: The government of the Central African Republic says it is in talks with Ugandan warlord Joseph Kony to get him to surrender.

item.title: Kenya in 'counter-terror abuses'
item.description: Kenyan counter-terrorism officers are accused of carrying out extra-judicial killings and other abuses in a report by US and Kenyan rights groups.

item.title: Jakarta halts people-smuggling help
item.description: Indonesia suspends military co-operation with Australia, including operations to combat people-smuggling - amid a row about reports Canberra spied on Jakarta officials.

item.title: Thai court rejects Senate changes
item.description: Thailand's Constitutional Court rejects government plans to amend the country's senate, but stops short of dissolving the governing Pheu Thai party.

item.title: Greenpeace suspects bailed in Russia
item.description: The captain and three Britons from on board a Greenpeace ship seized in the Arctic are granted bail by a Russian court as hearings continue.

item.title: MEPs push to leave Strasbourg site
item.description: The European Parliament calls for an EU treaty change to stop MEPs' expensive monthly shuttle to Strasbourg.

item.title: Venezuela leader gets special powers
item.description: Venezuela's congress gives final approval to controversial legislation allowing President Nicolas Maduro to govern by decrees for 12 months.

item.title: Sardinia swept by deadly cyclone
item.description: At least 18 people are killed in flooding after a cyclone lashes the island of Sardinia, prompting Italy to declare a state of emergency.

item.title: Baghdad struck by deadly bomb blasts
item.description: At least 29 people have been killed in a series of bomb attacks in mostly Shia districts of the Iraqi capital, Baghdad, officials and medics say.

item.title: Egyptian troops die in Sinai attack
item.description: Eleven Egyptian military personnel are killed and dozens more wounded in a car bomb attack near the North Sinai city of el-Arish.

item.title: Obama and Clinton visit JFK's grave
item.description: Barack Obama and Bill Clinton lay a wreath at the grave of John F Kennedy as part of a day of events honouring the assassinated president.

item.title: US neo-Nazi serial killer executed
item.description: A US white supremacist who targeted black and Jewish people in a nationwide killing spree is put to death in the US state of Missouri.

item.title: Day in pictures: 20 November 2013
item.description: 24 hours of news photos: 20 November

item.title: In pictures: The Hidden Mother
item.description: Keeping a child in front of the lens

item.title: In pictures: Beirut blasts
item.description: Double bombing in Lebanese capital

item.title: In pictures: Typhoon Haiyan aid stepped up
item.description: Aid starts to reach outlying areas

item.title: Day in pictures: 19 November 2013
item.description: 24 hours of news photos: 19 November

item.title: Last resting place: A glimpse into Colombian cemeteries
item.description: A glimpse into Colombian cemeteries

item.title: Week in pictures: 9-15 November 2013
item.description: News photos from around the world

item.title: In pictures: Children in Need telethon
item.description: Photos from a record-breaking night

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: The prime minister says there are "no plans" for an amnesty on crimes during the Troubles.

item.title: VIDEO: American Dr Who 'would use a gun'
item.description: As the Dr Who series turns 50 the BBC meets fans in the US to find out what makes a British Time Lord so popular.

item.title: VIDEO: Seal swims and plays with diver, 15
item.description: A scuba Diver had an unexpected visit from a seal on a dive off the Isle of Man coast.

item.title: VIDEO: Taxi drivers facing sat-nav ban
item.description: Taxi drivers in Bath look set to become the first in the country to be banned from using sat-navs for local journeys.

item.title: VIDEO: PM withdraws 'light-hearted' drugs jibe
item.description: David Cameron has been taken to task by a Labour MP who accused him of using an "unjustifiable, rude and offensive phrase" when replying to his question during PMQs.

item.title: VIDEO: Who are Hull's cultural icons?
item.description: Hull has been named as the UK's next City of Culture, but what are Hull's cultural highlights?

item.title: VIDEO: Obese man to travel home by ferry
item.description: A clinically obese Frenchman, prevented from travelling home by a number of flight and train operators, is to make his journey across the Channel by boat.

item.title: VIDEO: The lorry driver's London eye view
item.description: Getting spat at, avoiding errant cyclists and trying to overcome blind spots are all in a day's work for lorry driver Paul Hutchin.

item.title: VIDEO: Greenpeace activist's dad 'delighted'
item.description: The father of a British woman granted bail by a Russian court after being detained on a Greenpeace ship in the Arctic has told the BBC of his delight at the news.

item.title: The man who fixed his own heart
item.description: The man who found a way to fix his own heart

item.title: Ten fascinating facts about Hull
item.description: How much do you know about the UK's next City of Culture?

item.title: The story of how #ThankyouSachin got so big
item.description: The man with more than 3.5 million tweets

item.title: 8 radical solutions to protect cyclists
item.description: Should cars be banned from city centres to protect cyclists?

item.title: R.I.P. Tie Rack
item.description: Goodbye to a 1980s sartorial phenomenon

item.title: Tokyo Motor Show: New cars unveiled
item.description: World's leading carmakers show off their latest designs

item.title: Under fire on a dangerous Somali road
item.description: BBC experiences dangers faced by Somalia peacekeepers

item.title: Keane: Breakthroughs and breakdowns
item.description: Keane on the highs and lows of a decade of band life

item.title: UK newspapers: Thursday's front pages
item.description: A look at Thursday's front pages

item.title: Co-op Bank to be probed and probed
item.description: Co-op Bank to be probed and probed

item.title: Making a friendlier Raspberry Pi
item.description: The kit that aims to simplify DIY computer building
